snippet.textDisplay: I wanted to love the game and I did enjoy it to the point where I got stuck on trying to split a waterfall in to so I can reveal the hidden door behind it. This was when I understood from the online community that apparently you need to decipher some gibberish scribble nonsense and then some more crazy puzzles that were never a part of the learning curve through game play and the only way to know what to do is to go online and listen the exclamatory guides. It is like playing chess and all the sudden The opponent laying down a hand of cards exclaiming BlackJack and snatching your queen. The developers could not make up puzzles with the environment of the game so instead they bypassed all that and just placed some absolute travesty of riddles. This is because they failed to understand the mechanics of the game so they had to bypass it with whale secret alphabets and bird poop riddles that only the mad hatter can try to solve if he has enough tea from wild mushrooms. That's what happened when you steel a game mechanic that you don't understand and than bypass it with your own idea that only makes sense to you and no body else

snippet.textDisplay:
the funny thing is that Jon Blow made harsher comments on the Japanese game industry (modern Japanese games are a shitstain upon art) while Phil clarified his position (modern Japanese games are very samey, relying on the same mechanics and whatnot). At the same conference.

Still, that Twitter fiasco is pretty stupid even by Phil Fish standards. That's why I prefer my Polytron reps be Renaud.

snippet.textDisplay: why do ppl have to turn into such weaboos? yes, the modern japanese gaming industry is losing ground to western gaming industry, they are stuck in time and if you need proof, look at the lack of good jrpgs in the last 10 years....im not saying there arent any good japanese games now, but it is true that they arent what they used to be

snippet.textDisplay:
"FEZ has won the grand prize at both indiecade, and IGF. HOW DO YOU LIKE ME NOW."
"WE FUCKING WON"

Is that a natural human response to you? No, of course it isn't. 
Not to mention that guy ditches the japanese video game industry, saying how it sucks. I have nothing more to say. This conversation is over.

snippet.textDisplay:
Fez is a great and a unique game, but Phil Fish is still a dick. His egoistical and arrogant attitude is annoying me. For example when he got an award for his game, he bragged about it on Twitter.
Cave Story will still be the best indie game ever made, atleast to me. And with these rumours about Cave Story 2, I'm hoping the sequel will turn out to be a good game, and not a cash grab.
snippet.textOriginal:

Cave Story will still be the best indie game ever made, atleast to me. And with these rumours about Cave Story 2, I'm hoping the sequel will turn out to be a good game, and not a cash grab.

snippet.textDisplay: "A great musical score is an important component of all the greatest game worlds and so it proves with Fez. Improbably for a virtual space that is so weirdly constructed and illusive, Fez's world lives in my memory just as Hyrule or Azeroth do. I only need to hear a chord of [Disasterpeace]'s music to be transported there, and the thought of visiting it again and seeing its blood-orange sunsets fade﻿ into starry night makes my spine tingle. As a place, it's beautiful, evocative and magical."
snippet.textOriginal: "A great musical score is an important component of all the greatest game worlds and so it proves with Fez. Improbably for a virtual space that is so weirdly constructed and illusive, Fez's world lives in my memory just as Hyrule or Azeroth do. I only need to hear a chord of [Disasterpeace]'s music to be transported there, and the thought of visiting it again and seeing its blood-orange sunsets fade﻿ into starry night makes my spine tingle. As a place, it's beautiful, evocative and magical."

snippet.textDisplay: Two Fez uploads close to each other, like with Hotline Miami. Funny how it took inspiration from a couple oldschool platformers but still ended up being the most unique and memorable game I played﻿ all year. I wouldn't be surprised in a couple years if I ended up putting Fez at the #1 spot in 2012 (in terms of the games I played so far). Eurogamer chose this as their game of the year and wrote a nice article about it. Quote of choice:
